text:
♪ There you'll sample
Mrs. Lovett's meat pies ♪
♪ Savory and sweet pies, as you'll see ♪

♪ You who eat pies, Mrs.
Lovett's meat pies ♪
♪ Conjure up the treat pies used to be ♪
- [Andrew] Hey, what's up guys?

Welcome back to Binging with
Babish, where this week,

we're taking a look at the
morbid meat pies made of man

from Sweeney Todd: The Demon
Barber of Fleet Street.

As you can see, I've got a
nice pile of viscera here
to celebrate the Halloween season,
but it does serve a purpose.
What I have here is lamb kidney fat,
which has a rich, sweet, gamey flavor

that I think is gonna
be perfect for emulating
the human elements of our pie.

So we've got about two
pounds of lamb fat here

that I'm gonna cut into
chunks and render out

over medium-low heat,
stirring occasionally

so that it doesn't
burn, until it's yielded

about two cups of liquid fat,
maybe about half an hour,

which we're gonna strain
through a cheesecloth

and a fine mesh sieve so as
to catch any particulate.
Discard the solids and set aside.

Now we're gonna use it to
make hot water crust pastry,

combining 280 grams of water
and 110 grams of rendered

lamb fat in a small lidded
saucepan that we're gonna bring
to a simmer over medium heat.

While that's doing its thing,
I'm gonna tiny whisk together

a pinch of salt with 500
grams of all-purpose flour

before pouring the hot
fat and water over top,

which I'm gonna mix
together with a wooden spoon
until all the flour is hydrated.

Once no dry patches remain,
I'm gonna cover it up

and let it rest until it's
cool enough to handle,
about 20 minutes.

Now, the pies in the movie
looks like freestanding

hot water crust pastry,
which means that we need
some pretty thoroughly-developed gluten,
so I'm gonna knead this thing for about

five to seven minutes, until
it's firm but not tough,
like a loving father.

Then we're placing it into
a bowl and covering it,

once again letting it rest
at room temperature for,
this time about an hour, during which time
we can contend with our meat.

I tried my absolute
darndest to get human meat,
but the cops said no go.
But the Smithsonian describes human meat

as tasting like chuck roast,
so I have a grass-fed one here.

I think that between this
and our lamb fat pastry,
we should have a close approximation
of what a human pie tastes like.

So I'm breaking it down
into bite-sized pieces

and trimming off any sinew
or connective tissue,

sprinkling some fresh-picked
thyme over top, along with

a hefty pinch of kosher salt
and freshly-ground black pepper

and scattering some
onions in there as well.

This, to me, feels like
the spices and aromatics

they'd use in the 18th
century London kitchen.
Now that we've got our meat filling ready,
it's time to start forming our pastry.

I'm starting with maybe
a third of my dough

that I'ma roll out to an
eight to 10-inch round,

about two inches wider than I
want my resultant pie to be.

Then, using a bowl or
a crock like this one

as a sort of mold, we're
gonna shape the pie

up around the sides, pressing
and forming it together
until it holds its shape.
Then we're slicing off any uneven excess,

so we have a nice flat
top, to which we can
more easily adhere a pastry lid.

So go ahead and pop the
pastry shell off the mold,

and now's the time to fill it
with the ill-gotten entrails

of the former customers of
the barbershop upstairs,

pressing as much as we
possibly can in there,

because it is going to
shrink during cooking.

Now we're rolling out another
smaller piece of pastry,
about an inch wider than the pie,

brushing down the edges of
the pie with a beaten egg,
and draping the pastry lid over top.
Now I'm gonna chop off any tattered excess
and use the rest to crimp down,

being sure to seal shut
as thoroughly as possible,
so we don't spring any leaks in the oven.

Hot water crest is very
forgiving, so don't be afraid

to patch any spots you
feel might be weak points.

Now we're gonna cut a
steam vent in the center,

so the thing doesn't explode,
and optionally garnish

with what looked like some
little decorative pastry leaves.

The pies in the movie
didn't look super artisanal

or anything, so I'm not
gonna go too crazy here.

Just gonna cut up four
leaves of varying sizes
and adhere them to the top of the pie
with a little bit of egg wash.

Now this guy's headed into
a 350-degree Fahrenheit oven
for anywhere from one to two hours,

until the pastry is
beginning to lightly brown

and the beef registers run
160 degrees Fahrenheit.

Then we're thoroughly brushing
down every nook and/or cranny
with a beaten egg before returning
to a slightly hotter oven, 375 or 400,
for an additional 15 to 20 minutes,
or until golden brown and burnished.

Wait 10, 15 minutes until this
guy's cool enough to handle,
place him on a wire rack.
No soggy bottoms here, Paul Hollywood.

And ideally, you want to let
this guy cool completely,

about two hours, but I've got
a hungry Sawyer in the house,
so I thought I'd dig in early.

Now, my original plan was
for this to be the base

movie version, then I was
gonna make an improved
Babish version, but it was so good,
we ended up eating every bite.

So instead, I took him
upstairs to practice shaving
with a straight razor
(jazzy music)
